interventionPolicy.description: An intervention policy is a set of rules that reset the value of several parameters and state variables of a model, triggered at given timestep value or by some other model quantity passing a given threshold value; examples of public health intervention policies in the context of an epidemiological model include vaccination of high-risk individuals and quarantining of symptomatic individuals.

modelId.description: The ID of the AMR model to which the intervention policy applies.

name.description: A name for the intervention policy, such as 'Initial response of the Italian government to the COVID-19 epidemic'

description.description: A description of the overall intervention policy, such as 'Successive public health measures adopted by Italian policymakers over the first 38 days, as modelled by Giordano et al. 2020'

intervention.description: A set of rules that reset the value of parameters and state variables of a model, grouped by a decision made by policymakers and starting a particular date or timestep.

name.description: A name for the policymaker decision, such as 'Day 4 - closure of schools' or 'Day 12 - serology testing limited to symptomatic individuals'.

extractionPage.description: The page number where the model configuration was found in the text.

staticInterventions.description: A list of static interventions on a model, grouped here by the timestep at which the interventions occur.

dynamicInterventions.description: A list of dynamic interventions on a model, grouped here by the threshold-crossing event that trigger the interventions.

staticIntervention.description: A static intervention is a rule that reset the value of a parameter or state variable of the model at a given timestep value; examples include decreasing the value of the disease transmission rate between children after schools are closed after some date by policymakers.

appliedTo.description: The ID of the parameter or state variable to which the intervention is applied; for example, school closures cause a reduction in the disease transmission rate, which is represented by a parameter with some ID in the AMR model.

value.description: The new value to which the parameter or state variable of the model is reset; for example, the disease transmission rate is decreased to some value after schools are closed.

timestep.description: The timestep value at which the intervention is applied; for example, schools are closed 4 days after the first infection is detected.

dynamicIntervention.description: A dynamic intervention is a rule that reset the value of a parameter or state variable of the model, when some other state variable crosses a given threshold value, not a given timestep value; examples include increasing the serology testing rate when the proportion of hospitalized individuals exceeds some threshold value.

appliedTo.description: The ID of the parameter or state variable to which the intervention is applied; for example, the serology testing rate is represented by a parameter with some ID in the AMR model.

value.description: The new value to which the parameter or state variable of the model is reset; for example, the serology testing rate is increased to some value.

parameter.description: The ID of the state variable whose threshold crossing triggers this intervention; it cannot be a parameter; for example, the state variable is the proportion of hospitalized individuals.

threshold.description: The value at which the intervention-triggering state variable must cross for the value resetting rule to apply; for example, the proportion of hospitalized individuals exceeds some number and triggers the serology testing rate to increase.
